awd_titl_txt: Investigating Relationships Between Mathematical Knowledge for Teaching and High-Leverage Teaching Practices
awd_abstract_narration:
This proposal was submitted in response to EHR Core Research (ECR) program announcement NSF 15-509.  The ECR program of fundamental research in STEM education provides funding in critical research areas that are essential, broad and enduring. EHR seeks proposals that will help synthesize, build and/or expand research foundations in the following focal areas: STEM learning, STEM learning environments, STEM workforce development, and broadening participation in STEM. The ECR program is distinguished by its emphasis on the accumulation of robust evidence to inform efforts to (a) understand, (b) build theory to explain, and (c) suggest interventions (and innovations) to address persistent challenges in STEM interest, education, learning, and participation.

The proposed research will examine STEM learning environments and STEM workforce development. The proposed project will use simulations with student teachers to explore the relationship between preservice teachers' mathematics knowledge for teaching (MKT) and their ability to promote student learning in a sample of the content areas covered in K-6 mathematics curriculum (e.g., number operations, and area).

This research will accomplish three aims. It will contribute to foundational knowledge and theory about the relationships between mathematical knowledge for teaching and student teachers skill with eliciting and interpreting student thinking. It will provide the field with initial findings about the impact of design choices on the utility of a simulation for assessing MKT and HLPs, as well as critical insights on the utility of the simulation for nurturing the development of mathematical knowledge. Finally, it will contribute to the training of preservice teachers by developing actual simulations, including materials for implementing, which can be used to assess and enhance the MKT of preservice teachers.

por.por_cntn:
Mathematics teachers draw on their knowledge, skills, and dispositions to craft and enact learning experiences for students. Teacher preparation typically involves the development of mathematical knowledge, teaching practices, and dispositions with the aim of nurturing teachers capable of skillfully harnessing specialized knowledge of content and insights into students’ thinking and development as they teach. Insights into the interaction between knowledge, skill, and disposition within the teaching of preservice teachers hold the potential to enhance the aims and conduct of teacher preparation. This project employed teaching simulations, similar to those used in the preparation of professionals in other fields, to investigate relationships between preservice teachers’ mathematical knowledge for teaching in the area of number and operations and the nature of their eliciting and interpreting of student thinking related to problems in number and operation. Further, the project explored features of simulations, and surrounding routines and experiences, that could assess mathematical knowledge and/or support the development of mathematical knowledge.

Simulations were developed to learn about the role that mathematical knowledge and disposition may play in preservice teachers’ teaching practices of eliciting and interpreting student thinking. In one study, we assessed the mathematical knowledge and disposition of preservice teachers concerning the particular algorithms that would be shown subsequently in student work and would be the basis of interactions with a standardized student within a simulation. The purpose of the simulation interaction was to learn about each student’s process and understanding of that process. By varying the mathematical content in the simulations with respect to the preservice teachers’ mathematical knowledge of, and disposition toward, the algorithms involved, we were able to analyze the potential impacts of the preservice teachers’ knowledge and disposition on teaching. While eliciting and interpreting procedural elements of the student thinking looked relatively similar across simulations, the teaching differed when seeking and interpreting information about student understanding of algorithms. Specifically, in situations where preservice teachers had relatively strong mathematical knowledge and positive disposition, they more thoroughly elicited and better interpreted student understanding compared to those preservice teachers who had weaker mathematical knowledge and more negative dispositions. Interestingly, mathematical knowledge appeared to support identifying key features of understanding, whereas disposition appeared to drive the quality of interpretation when particular understandings were designated. In sum, there appears to be a nuanced relationship between knowledge, disposition, and teaching practice.

In a companion study, we developed and studied variations on simulations to examine the potential effects of changes in simulation features on opportunities to assess and support the learning of mathematics for teaching by preservice teachers. The study explored changes to salient features both within and surrounding a simulation. One feature explored was the inclusion of two pieces of student work that focused on the same problem, showing two different approaches and differing answers. The second feature explored was the way that standardized students responded to questions and initiated particular interactions, such as offering additional examples, describing their disposition toward learning, and requesting an explanation. This varied by study condition. The third feature explored concerned the work surrounding the simulation. In one condition, preservice teachers had the potential to participate in designed reflection activity involving the connection of their simulation experiences with resources that further explained the mathematics at the heart of the simulation. While changes to simulation features did not show significant effects on the learning of mathematical knowledge, they did expand opportunities to assess preservice teachers’ skill in eliciting student thinking, producing situationally embedded explanations of mathematical ideas, and supporting student learning grounded connections between student work samples.

This project contributes to the field in several respects. First, it contributes concretely by connecting foundational knowledge and theory relevant to teacher preparation to the nature of actual preservice teachers’ eliciting and interpreting of student thinking under standardized conditions. Second, it provides the field with initial findings of the impact of design choices on the utility of a simulation for assessing mathematical knowledge for teaching and high-leverage teaching practices. Third, it contributes to the training of future preservice teachers by developing actual simulations that can be used to assess and/or enhance the mathematical knowledge for teaching of preservice teachers.
